utterances: Working in a Sri Lankan or Delhian(ph) restaurant in Canada is completely different.
Here it's already made things.
When you get a pizza in Sri Lanka I will be making the pizza dough and everything, so it's about two hours.
Here it's readymade, so it's very easy to work here.
And staff like Sangeya have made Andy Parker's work easier too.
Moxie's owner says he's so pleased with his new employees he's applied for 15 more from Sri Lanka.
He'll employ them at a restaurant he owns in Grand Prairie, another Alberta boomtown.
Frank Langfitt, NPR News.
You can go see the oil sands operations for yourself, take a video tour, and hear part one of this report, at npr.org.
Some physical therapists are getting better at treating back pain.
It's no longer the one-size fits all approach, where everybody was told to use heat, massage, and stretching.
Now, therapists have a way to evaluate a patient and predict which kind of treatment or exercise will work the fastest.
NPR's Allison Aubrey reports.
Four years ago, schoolteacher Maureen Colhane was working with a bunch of elementary students, when one child jumped on her, meaning to give her a big hug.
I felt something go.
It was just a feeling.
I held back the tears until I got in the hallway, and then the counselor said, what has happened to you?
Colhane says she could hardly walk, and despite a doctor's prognosis that she would get better with time, her pain was relentless.
I had steroid injections--24 to 48 hours relief.
Massages--24, 48 hours.
Nothing lasted longer than that.
One physical therapist recommended back stretches that made the pain worse.
Another therapist told her to keep trying them, that it would take time.
But Colhane knew something wasn't right.

So, with some research and a referral from a friend, she landed in the office of Jennifer Muller Gamboa, one of the therapists who uses the thorough spine evaluation approach to guide her treatment recommendations.
She came in with a functional outcome score of 75 percent disability.
That's huge.
You know, that tells you that something is not working.
Easier.
And when you go into a medical marijuana dispensary, what do you look for?
But strangely, Savage has the feeling of total self-reliance brought her peace.
The Atlantic also taught her the absolute necessity of positive thinking, something she'll need for the Pacific, a much tougher journey.
It'll be carried out in three stages and is more than double the distance of the Atlantic.
She knows it will be grueling.
I don't have children, but I'm guessing that rowing an ocean is maybe a little bit childbirth.
That after a while you forget the real pain of it and you convince yourself that it's something you'd quite like to get through again.
She's also spurred on this time by a cause she is passionate about, the Blue Frontier Campaign, a non-profit group dedicated to cleaning up the world's oceans.
Depending on winds and tides, Savage is expected to launch sometime between July 11th and the 13th.
For NPR News, I'm Jenny Brundin.
From NPR News, it's DAY TO DAY with Marketplace, and what is with the markets?
If they got any happier, they trade the opening bell for a fit of the giggles.
The Dow's breaking records and the Chinese Stock Exchange in Shanghai, totally recovered from a mini-crash in February.
Steve Tripoli from Marketplace.
Steve, what is it?
Where is all these optimism coming from?
We'll, it's coming from every corner of the globe, I'm afraid, Alex.
I hate to be such a non-alarmist about this.
Yeah, quick quiz - you mentioned those stock markets across Asia yesterday, including Australia and New Zealand, record highs; U.S.
stock market, 21 of the past 24 sessions, the longest stretch in 52 years.
These all feeds off good news in economic growth from every continent.
From ever continent - including Africa, which often lags - and that's just the partial list.
So you think this is a real deal - not some kind of condition that we're in or is this a quirky little spur and the rollercoaster's going to dip again in the moment?
Well, it's apparently the real deal - at least according to the World Bank's chief economist, Andrew Burns, who I spoke with today.
Here's what he says.
This is a very strong period of economic growth throughout the world.
What we can say is that we've had four years in which developing country growth has exceeded five percent.
So that's already an indication that there's something more than just a one-off effect going on here.
So, Steve, what is propelling all these?
Well, it's going to sound obvious but growth begets growth?
And you know, people are making more and selling more.
The selling part raises living standards worldwide.
A lot of people joined the middle class.
That creates more new markets and more economic activity.
It's really just, Alex, the virtuous circle out of every economics textbook.
Well, I know you know a lot about virtuous circles.
But tell me, how long is this one going to endure?
Well, it can last.
I mean, it's not certain it'll last.
Andrew Burns at the World Bank tells me that this period of growth has more solid underpinnings in past periods, more good news.
Why?
Because developing countries are better organized economically, they're not getting in over their heads.
There's - some of them are even retiring debt so the conditions are in place for a soft landing when all these growth slows down.
Well, what about slowing down?
Is there something that will derail it?
Oh, a lot of things could derail it.
You know, maybe the most plausible if the growth goes a little too fast.
There are already signs of that, especially in Asia.
That raises the prices of raw materials like oil and metals and that leads to some inflation, which slows down growth.
And some of the scarier scenarios are here on the U.S.
Is the housing bust going to be a big drag?
Could the subprime lending crisis get worse?

All the investment money that's floating around the world these days has launched a lot of high-flying deals using this - could that debt thing unwind fast and hard if people have to come up with real cash all of a sudden?
You know, Steve, I know there's tremendous growth in Asia, but I also think that there are huge numbers of people left behind, and that inequality must seem like some kind of problem.
It is.
You're absolutely right.

You know, the minority that's dislocated by the world economy is a factor, and world leaders are starting to understand that those folks need shock absorbers to cushion the change they're seeing or else we're in danger of getting a backlash against this kind of globalization, like trade protectionism, and that's could slow down all these good news we're hearing for everybody.
Thank you.
Steve Tripoli of Public Radio's daily business show, Marketplace from American Public Media.
(Soundbite of music)
DAY TO DAY will be back in a moment.
Let's start by talking about this very important announcement that is supposed to come on Monday - President Trump's choice to replace Justice Anthony Kennedy on the Supreme Court.
The president spent the weekend at his resort in Bedminster, N.J., where he reportedly spent time on the final decision.
As he boarded Air Force One, the president said he's close to making a final decision and that he's narrowed the list down to four candidates.
President Trump has said previously that he is unlikely to ask potential nominees whether they support Roe v.
Wade, the landmark case that legalized abortion in 1973.
But it is clear that that decision looms very large in the coming debate over who will fill this seat.

Many Democrats and some Republicans say it is critical to know where a potential justice stands on the question of whether legal precedents governing abortion rights will be affirmed by the next justice.
But this comes at a time when nominees have been revealing less and less about themselves before they are confirmed.
We wanted to talk about this, so we called legal affairs correspondent Nina Totenberg, who's with us now.
Welcome.
Thank you for having me.
So, Nina, first, you know, from the outside, this process seems disingenuous.
The president said repeatedly during the campaign that he wants to see Roe overturned, and that's a goal that is shared by many social conservatives.
And, obviously, progressives want somebody who will not overturn Roe.
Now, you're closer than the rest of us to this process.
Is it true that the focus of this selection really is what will happen to Roe v.
Wade?
Today's personal health report focuses on the mental health of young people.
Parents and school boards in some communities are being asked to decided whether to support mental health screening for teen-agers.
NPR's Joanne Silberner reports.
TeenScreen is a six-year-old program that surveys about 14,000 middle and high school students in 42 states.
The kids take a 10-minute questionnaire at school.
The questions were designed by Columbia University psychiatrists to identify kids with behaviors and feelings associated with suicide attempts.
At an orientation for counselors from East Penn School District in Pennsylvania, TeenScreen's Tiffany Haick explained the program's rationale.
We know that mental illness is so often treatable.
We know that most mentally ill and suicidal kids are not already getting any help.
We know there's ample time to intervene before a teen dies by suicide.
We think that if we ask these kids the right questions in the right safe space and environment that they'll give us the honest answers.
And really, and I think most importantly, no one else is asking these kids these questions.
Haick emphasized the importance of getting consent from both the parents and the students, and she demonstrated the computer program that asks kids a sequence of questions like these.
(Soundbite of computer program)
Have you often felt very nervous when you've had to do things in front of people?
For this question, I want to know if you have ever had a sudden attack of feeling very afraid.
There are questions about loneliness, about relationships, about personal behaviors, about suicide.
Some families say the program is intrusive and dangerous, including the Rhoades family of northern Indiana.
Chelsea Rhoades, now 17, went through the TeenScreen program a year ago.
She says after her screening, she was pulled aside by a counselor.
She's, like, `Well, by this chart, it seems that you have social anxiety and OCD,' and I'm, like, `For what?
And she goes, `Possibly cleaning,' and I'm just like, `What?'
Her mother, Teresa Rhoades, was upset when her daughter told her about it.

I told her that there was absolutely nothing wrong with the fact that she liked to keep her room clean or that she was expected to do her housework when she came home every day because that's the way that we've raised her.
And most important, Teresa Rhoades says she never signed a permission slip.
